headline: EU top court refers WhatsApp's fight against EU privacy watchdog back to lower tribunal
summary: Europe's top court on Tuesday sent Meta Platforms ​unit WhatsApp's fight against the ‌EU privacy watchdog back to a lower tribunal, ‌prolonging a five-year tussle triggered by the latter's order to the Irish data protection authority to jack up a ⁠fine to ‌225 million euro ($268 million). "The action brought by WhatsApp Ireland against ‍Binding Decision 1/2021 of the European Data Protection Board is admissible," the Luxembourg-based Court of ​Justice of the European Union ‌said. The Irish privacy enforcer ratcheted up its fine against WhatsApp in 2021 after the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) intervened.

content.title: EU top court refers WhatsApp's fight against EU privacy watchdog back to lower tribunal
content.summary: Europe's top court on Tuesday sent Meta Platforms ​unit WhatsApp's fight against the ‌EU privacy watchdog back to a lower tribunal, ‌prolonging a five-year tussle triggered by the latter's order to the Irish data protection authority to jack up a ⁠fine to ‌225 million euro ($268 million). "The action brought by WhatsApp Ireland against ‍Binding Decision 1/2021 of the European Data Protection Board is admissible," the Luxembourg-based Court of ​Justice of the European Union ‌said. The Irish privacy enforcer ratcheted up its fine against WhatsApp in 2021 after the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) intervened.

headline: WhatsApp's fight against $268 million Irish privacy fine sent back to lower tribunal
summary: Meta Platforms unit WhatsApp's fight against the EU privacy watchdog was sent back to ​a lower tribunal on Tuesday, prolonging a five-year tussle triggered by the ‌latter's order to the Irish data protection authority to increase a fine to 225 million euros ($268 million).  The case ‌is one of many for Ireland's DPC, which is the lead privacy regulator for most of the U.S. tech giants due to the location of their EU head offices in the country.  Ireland's regulator took action following complaints about WhatsApp's use of personal data in ⁠the country, later upping its ‌fine in 2021 after the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) intervened.

content.title: WhatsApp's fight against $268 million Irish privacy fine sent back to lower tribunal
content.summary: Meta Platforms unit WhatsApp's fight against the EU privacy watchdog was sent back to ​a lower tribunal on Tuesday, prolonging a five-year tussle triggered by the ‌latter's order to the Irish data protection authority to increase a fine to 225 million euros ($268 million).  The case ‌is one of many for Ireland's DPC, which is the lead privacy regulator for most of the U.S. tech giants due to the location of their EU head offices in the country.  Ireland's regulator took action following complaints about WhatsApp's use of personal data in ⁠the country, later upping its ‌fine in 2021 after the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) intervened.

headline: Tech Weekly: big tech in court, Alibaba's AI Olympic fashion
summary:
STORY: From big tech in the dock to Alibaba's AI helping winter Olympic guests choose outfits. 

This is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Meta Platforms and YouTube deliberately designed products they knew would addict children.

That's what a lawyer for a woman suing the Big Tech companies told jurors in California.

The trial will test whether Big Tech platforms can be held liable for their app design.

The 20-year-old woman identified as Kaley G.M. in court is suing Instagram-parent Meta Platforms and YouTube-owner, Alphabet's Google,.

Her lawyer says she was hooked on social media at a young age because of the apps' addictive design.

The Australian government has called a meeting with gaming platform Roblox.

It's over reports of child grooming and exposure to graphic content on the platform.

While a regulator said it will test whether Roblox had delivered on child-safety commitments.

Researchers at the University of Bristol are developing soft robotic "exosuit" trousers worn under a spacesuit.

They say it could help astronauts move more naturally while reducing lower-limb fatigue during future Moon and Mars missions.

The team said the technology could also support mobility and physical rehabilitation on Earth.

Including systems that either assist movement or add resistance to help maintain muscle mass.

Elon Musk has said that SpaceX has shifted its focus to building a "self‑growing city" on the moon.

He says this could be achieved in less than 10 years.

Musk wrote on his X social media platform that SpaceX still intends to start on his long-held ambition of a city on Mars within five to seven years.

But that the quote, "overriding priority is securing the future of civilization and the Moon is faster."

Alibaba's AI tech is helping Olympic guests dress up in Milan.

From slick outfits to tailored makeup and elegant fragrance, Alibaba is offering visitors a futuristic shopping experience powered by latest AI technology.

In the “Wonder on Ice” showcase, visitors explore the virtual retail and an avatar of their own being created.

“Ciao, Claire. Finally we meet. I’m so glad you accepted our invitation to this fantasy gala.”

Visitors can then select their preferred clothing and makeup styles with recommendations made by a virtual guide.

content.title: Tech Weekly: big tech in court, Alibaba's AI Olympic fashion

:: Tech Weekly

Her lawyer says she was hooked on social media at a young age because of the apps' addictive design.

It's over reports of child grooming and exposure to graphic content on the platform.

While a regulator said it will test whether Roblox had delivered on child-safety commitments.

Researchers at the University of Bristol are developing soft robotic "exosuit" trousers worn under a spacesuit.

They say it could help astronauts move more naturally while reducing lower-limb fatigue during future Moon and Mars missions.

The team said the technology could also support mobility and physical rehabilitation on Earth.

Including systems that either assist movement or add resistance to help maintain muscle mass.

Elon Musk has said that SpaceX has shifted its focus to building a "self‑growing city" on the moon.

He says this could be achieved in less than 10 years.

Musk wrote on his X social media platform that SpaceX still intends to start on his long-held ambition of a city on Mars within five to seven years.

But that the quote, "overriding priority is securing the future of civilization and the Moon is faster."

Alibaba's AI tech is helping Olympic guests dress up in Milan.

From slick outfits to tailored makeup and elegant fragrance, Alibaba is offering visitors a futuristic shopping experience powered by latest AI technology.

In the “Wonder on Ice” showcase, visitors explore the virtual retail and an avatar of their own being created.

“Ciao, Claire. Finally we meet. I’m so glad you accepted our invitation to this fantasy gala.”

Visitors can then select their preferred clothing and makeup styles with recommendations made by a virtual guide.

headline: Big Investors Doubled Down on AI Stocks, Study Finds
summary: University endowments, charities and the ultrawealthy increased investments in artificial intelligence-related stocks last year, according to a research brief expected to be published Tuesday.  It found the biggest increases in exposure in 2025 were in two categories of stocks: those classified as information technology and those classified as communication services—a group that includes Alphabet and Meta Platforms.  The analysis focused on book value to filter out the impact of many tech and communications stocks’ rapid increase in market value.

content.title: Big Investors Doubled Down on AI Stocks, Study Finds
content.summary: University endowments, charities and the ultrawealthy increased investments in artificial intelligence-related stocks last year, according to a research brief expected to be published Tuesday.  It found the biggest increases in exposure in 2025 were in two categories of stocks: those classified as information technology and those classified as communication services—a group that includes Alphabet and Meta Platforms.  The analysis focused on book value to filter out the impact of many tech and communications stocks’ rapid increase in market value.

headline: WhatsApp wins court backing to challenge $268 million Irish privacy fine
summary: Meta Platforms' WhatsApp on Tuesday won backing from Europe's top court for its challenge to ​a fine that was increased to 225 million euros ($268 million) by the EU ‌privacy watchdog, a ruling that could pave the way for similar action by other companies.  It fined WhatsApp following complaints about its use of personal data in the country, later increasing the penalty it imposed after the European Data Protection Board intervened in ⁠2021.  The DPC has only collected 17.5 ‌million euros of the more than 4 billion euros it has fined large tech companies for GDPR breaches since 2020 due to all but ‍two of its completed investigations being subjected to lengthy legal challenges, many to similar EDPB interventions.

content.title: WhatsApp wins court backing to challenge $268 million Irish privacy fine
content.summary: Meta Platforms' WhatsApp on Tuesday won backing from Europe's top court for its challenge to ​a fine that was increased to 225 million euros ($268 million) by the EU ‌privacy watchdog, a ruling that could pave the way for similar action by other companies.  It fined WhatsApp following complaints about its use of personal data in the country, later increasing the penalty it imposed after the European Data Protection Board intervened in ⁠2021.  The DPC has only collected 17.5 ‌million euros of the more than 4 billion euros it has fined large tech companies for GDPR breaches since 2020 due to all but ‍two of its completed investigations being subjected to lengthy legal challenges, many to similar EDPB interventions.

headline: TSMC Revenue Jumps 37% in January as AI Spending Marches On
summary: The contract chipmaker for Nvidia Corp. reported a 37% rise in January revenue to NT$401.3 billion ($12.7 billion), above the 30% revenue growth TSMC expects for the full year.  TSMC, which also produces chips for Apple Inc., has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of a surge in artificial intelligence-related investment, due to its role in manufacturing advanced AI accelerators.  Demand for data center chips in particular is spurring TSMC to earmark as much as $56 billion in capital spending this year, which would be up a quarter from 2025.

content.title: TSMC Revenue Jumps 37% in January as AI Spending Marches On
content.summary: The contract chipmaker for Nvidia Corp. reported a 37% rise in January revenue to NT$401.3 billion ($12.7 billion), above the 30% revenue growth TSMC expects for the full year.  TSMC, which also produces chips for Apple Inc., has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of a surge in artificial intelligence-related investment, due to its role in manufacturing advanced AI accelerators.  Demand for data center chips in particular is spurring TSMC to earmark as much as $56 billion in capital spending this year, which would be up a quarter from 2025.

headline: Meta subsidiary loses appeal against Deutsche Telekom over network services
summary: A ​German court ‌has ruled that ‌Meta subsidiary Edge Network Services must ⁠pay ‌Deutsche Telekom about 30 ‍million euros ($35.71 million) that the ​German telecoms ‌firm claims it is owed for providing network ⁠services used ​by ​the U.S company's platforms, a ‍court ⁠spokesperson said on Tuesday. (Reporting ⁠by Miranda MurrayEditing ‌by Madeline ‌Chambers)

headline: Wizz Joins Tech Coalition As One of Only Three European Members of the Leading Child Safety Alliance
summary: PARIS, February 10, 2026--Wizz, the social discovery app for GenZ to build community globally, today announced it has become a member of the Tech Coalition. This global industry alliance is dedicated to combating online child sexual exploitation and abuse (OCSEA). Wizz is now one of only three European companies among the Coalition's membership, which includes major platforms such as Google, Meta, Microsoft, and Snap, Inc..

headline: Meta unit must pay Deutsche Telekom $36 million over network services, German court say
summary: A German court has ruled that a Meta subsidiary must pay Deutsche Telekom about 30 million euros ($35.71 ​million) for network services used by the U.S company's platforms, a ‌court spokesperson said on Tuesday.  The payment covers services that Telekom says it provided over more ‌than three years to handle internet traffic generated by Meta platforms such as Facebook and Instagram.  At issue was whether a binding contract existed during this period for the use of Telekom's "peering points," where data enters the company's network.

content.title: Meta unit must pay Deutsche Telekom $36 million over network services, German court say
content.summary: A German court has ruled that a Meta subsidiary must pay Deutsche Telekom about 30 million euros ($35.71 ​million) for network services used by the U.S company's platforms, a ‌court spokesperson said on Tuesday.  The payment covers services that Telekom says it provided over more ‌than three years to handle internet traffic generated by Meta platforms such as Facebook and Instagram.  At issue was whether a binding contract existed during this period for the use of Telekom's "peering points," where data enters the company's network.

headline: Telegram faces further restrictions, possible fines as Russian authorities clamp down
summary: Telegram, an important platform for public and private communications in Russia, will face further restrictions from the authorities because it has failed to correct previous violations, ​the state communications watchdog said.  The watchdog, Roskomnadzor, began limiting voice and video calls via Telegram last August, ‌when it took similar steps against Meta's WhatsApp.  In ‌a statement on Tuesday, Roskomnadzor said a number of messaging apps, including Telegram, had not taken action over the past few months to address its complaints against them.

content.title: Telegram faces further restrictions, possible fines as Russian authorities clamp down
content.summary: Telegram, an important platform for public and private communications in Russia, will face further restrictions from the authorities because it has failed to correct previous violations, ​the state communications watchdog said.  The watchdog, Roskomnadzor, began limiting voice and video calls via Telegram last August, ‌when it took similar steps against Meta's WhatsApp.  In ‌a statement on Tuesday, Roskomnadzor said a number of messaging apps, including Telegram, had not taken action over the past few months to address its complaints against them.

headline: CME Group to Launch Single Stock Futures
summary: CME Group, the world's leading derivatives marketplace, today announced plans to launch Single Stock futures beginning this summer, pending completion of all regulatory review and processes. These new products will enable market participants to trade futures on more than 50 of the top U.S. stocks from the S&P 500, Nasdaq-100 and Russell 1000 indices, including names such as Alphabet, Meta, NVIDIA and Tesla – all with the flexibility, capital efficiency and precision of financially settled future

headline: European Watch Company Launches Crown & Caliber as Online Luxury Lifestyle Magazine
summary: BOSTON, February 10, 2026--European Watch Company (EWC), the Boston-based, family-owned leader in pre-owned luxury timepieces, today reintroduces Crown & Caliber (C&C) as an online luxury lifestyle magazine. The new Crown & Caliber pairs horological authority with broader cultural storytelling, delivering daily coverage of watches, style, travel, and experiences that celebrate a life well lived.

content.title: European Watch Company Launches Crown & Caliber as Online Luxury Lifestyle Magazine
content.summary: BOSTON, February 10, 2026--European Watch Company (EWC), the Boston-based, family-owned leader in pre-owned luxury timepieces, today reintroduces Crown & Caliber (C&C) as an online luxury lifestyle magazine. The new Crown & Caliber pairs horological authority with broader cultural storytelling, delivering daily coverage of watches, style, travel, and experiences that celebrate a life well lived.

headline: S&P 500 Struggles to Break Through Closing High Ahead of Jobs Report
summary: The Dow was set to build on yesterday’s closing high with a gain of 250 points, or 0.5%.  “I think the market is happy that the constant parade of sort of crazy policy declarations or tariff threats from the White House has calmed down,” Sevens Report Research’s Tom Essaye told Barron’s. “So that’s helping.”  For the S&P and Nasdaq, key Magnificent Seven stocks including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Apple, and Nvidia were a drag.

content.title: S&P 500 Struggles to Break Through Closing High Ahead of Jobs Report
content.summary: The Dow was set to build on yesterday’s closing high with a gain of 250 points, or 0.5%.  “I think the market is happy that the constant parade of sort of crazy policy declarations or tariff threats from the White House has calmed down,” Sevens Report Research’s Tom Essaye told Barron’s. “So that’s helping.”  For the S&P and Nasdaq, key Magnificent Seven stocks including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Apple, and Nvidia were a drag.

headline: Telegram app faces further restrictions, possible fines as Russian authorities clamp down
summary: Telegram, an important platform for public and private communications in Russia, will face further restrictions from authorities because it has failed to correct previous violations, the state communications watchdog said ​on Tuesday.  The watchdog, Roskomnadzor, began limiting voice and video calls via Telegram last August, when it took similar steps ‌against Meta's WhatsApp.  Telegram's Russian-born founder, entrepreneur Pavel Durov, defended the ‌app, saying it would remain committed to protecting freedom of speech and user privacy "no matter the pressure."

content.title: Telegram app faces further restrictions, possible fines as Russian authorities clamp down
content.summary: Telegram, an important platform for public and private communications in Russia, will face further restrictions from authorities because it has failed to correct previous violations, the state communications watchdog said ​on Tuesday.  The watchdog, Roskomnadzor, began limiting voice and video calls via Telegram last August, when it took similar steps ‌against Meta's WhatsApp.  Telegram's Russian-born founder, entrepreneur Pavel Durov, defended the ‌app, saying it would remain committed to protecting freedom of speech and user privacy "no matter the pressure."

thumbnail.caption: Illustration shows Telegram app logo
